([ "body":"Due to the nature of Docktown, and the importance of the docks, it is essential that trade goods that arrive in the city can be brought to the Market in Newtown without risk or or loss.\\n\\nThe proposal is to have guards patrol Market Street as well as the Docks to ensure that no muggers assault or steal any merchandise that come in by ship.\\n\\nAlternatively, set up a corps of guards who stand ready to escort shipments to Newtown where things are safer.\\n\\n[ooc: the idea is, once shipments are actually affected by the crime and muggers in Docktown, then it should be possible to have guards protect those shipments so they can arrive in Newtown. If not, then there will be lost shipments in the auction house (from those coming in by ship which a good bunch ought to be doing). It could create some RP and some fun if we have a type of NPC shipments moving from the Docks to Newtown, that PCs can either protect or assault, or invest in to protect.]", "comments":([ \:([ "comment":"Makes sense", "time":1481410702 ]), \:([ "comment":"--ooc-- i like this idea, it gives both lawful or guard characters a ig purpose. it also gives criminal characters a way to be criminals without inciting a mob intent on destroying your character.---\\r\\n\\r\\nI can see the need for this proposal. this will however require manpower and money. \\r\\n\\r\\nthe cost could go to the shipper or to the buyer but then prices of the import would likely raise. \\r\\n\\r\\nwe could have a place where guards could be hired as needed instead of having standby guards. ", "time":1479602979 ]), \:([ "comment":"At the meeting that took place on the 12th of Night, the matter was voted YES and upon later communications with the Sailor's Guild, they have pledged to ensure this happens with support of the Council toward such end.\\r\\n", "time":1495590513 ]) ]), "estimate":"Daily cost of 24d, 4 patrols of 3 guards.", "filedby":"Antonia", "location":"Docktown part of Market Street and the Docks", "title":"Safe passage" ])

([ "body":"An more upper scale restaurant than Mamma's in Docktown, serving traditional Triskellian foods and some specialities from other areas.\\n\\nThe Gilded Balance sells mainly seafood, so those restaurant could sell finer meats and vegetables, and be a place for the genteel to go out for dinner and business meetings without disturbing the casual gatherings in the Gilded Balance, nor have to go to Docktown for a meal.\\n\\nConverting an existing building into a finder restaurant would be rather expensive as marbles likely would need importing for the flooring, nicer woods for the walls and furniture.\\n\\nMarble: 1000d\\nWooden wall decorations: 1000d\\nFurniture: 1000d\\nDecorations: 500d\\nWorkers: 1500d\\n\\nCosts would fairly quickly be recovered through the increased number of visitors to Newtown, as well as property taxes and sales taxes on the food.\\n", "comments":([ \:([ "comment":"I'm in agreement with this, I would enjoy a proper restaurant where I can eat and enjoy my meal in peace.", "time":1479585030 ]), \:([ "comment":"Liguria Trading hopes that a private investor will step forth with a finished business plan that the Guild Council can grant permission to, and thereby open a restaurant soon in Newtown, but I do agree that it is not a priority nor a matter for the Guild Council currently.", "time":1480781473 ]), \:([ "comment":"There is already a cafe and the Inn serves wonderful food. ([ "body":"Seeing how unsafe Docktown has become, it will be necessary to build a hospital in Newtown.\\n\\nThe suggested location is due to several considerations:\\n- it is a quiet place of town\\n- Dunwasser Field is nearby, for strolls in the park by patients so they can recover faster\\n- close to the college for students and scholarly research and experiments\\n- close to the bathhouse, which means hot water will be easy to direct to the hospital, improving in hygiene and comfort\\n- close to the cathedral for clerical aid, bringing patience for blessings and so on\\n- close to the North Gate and easy to find for guests and next of kin to visit and find\\n\\nPrice estimate is based on what the infirmary cost to create down in Docktown several years ago, and doubled as this is Newtown and there will be running hot water also.\\n\\nThe hospital would contain:\\n- Shared infirmary with beds and partitions\\n- A couple of private rooms for those who can afford/are willing to pay for it\\n- Apothecary workshop for medications and the making of them\\n- Surgery room\\n- Running water\\n- Heating through hot-air vents\\n\\nMarble and stone would need to be imported, crafters employed to do the work, beds and furniture made, linens, towels and other things made and so on. ([ "body":"A guild hall for a group of crafts, where it will be beneficial to share locales and rooms.\\n\\nThe hall would have a number of rooms that can be rented by each individual guild, and have a shared common room that is equipped for and can be used as workshop and for socializing.\\n\\nThe rented rooms could consist of a storage room for shared resources for the guild members, and a meeting room for guild meetings. ([ "body":"There are many children in Triskellian who do not have the opportunity to properly learn all they can. We should make sure they have every opportunity that they can to become something other than a beggar, mugger or something worse.\\n\\nThis could be done a number of ways, one that came to mind was perhaps having denizens volunteer to teach the children. Crafters, scholars, constables, and much more. With further discussion I'm positive something can be agreed upon.\\n", "comments":([ \:([ "comment":"Thank you, Lady Antonia. I will contact the people you mentioned.", "time":1480693519 ]), \:([ "comment":"I still insist that this is something the Church should fund if they believe it to be a just cause. ", "time":1480127257 ]), \:([ "comment":"Children are traditionally taken in as apprentices in various guilds, or in direct service to houses and nobles.\\r\\nMany of the children you see roaming the streets seemingly without purpose are likely part of the thieves guild or other criminal organisations, plying their trade.\\r\\nThe Church does in connection with the Orphanage teach those interested how to read and write, and the Church is normally more than willing to take in any child willing, and train them in the ways of religious and devoted life.\\r\\nI can only agree with the above statements, a matter such as this would fall under the authority of the Church, and I can only encourage you to personally bring up the matter with the Church's representatives. ([ "body":"This proposal is for the building of the Newtown Carpenters Shop as previously approved by the Guild Council during the meeting on (OOC: 23 May 2017). ([ "body":"As an Idea to tend to the import issues and hoarding of imports. The cost of items tends to become out of reach for any normal person.\\n\\nI suggest a public warehouse that all the houses and sailors can use. Imports entering the city will, by default go to this warehouse that will be managed and operated by the City Watch Group. What this warehouse will offer is the ability for anyone within the city to stop and see every single imported item and who owns it. Once a person finds an item of interest. they can write to the owner and negotiate a selling price on the said item. Once agreed. the owner can submit the release request with the city watch stating that said item is to be sold for X amount to X person. \\n\\nA fee for this transaction would be identical to the tent market located on market street in docktown. Each transaction will cost the seller one denarii. The consumer will pay the watch for said item and the watch will forward the coin for that sell. minus the fee. to the former owner of the import. By doing this. All houses can bring in everything they possibly can and keep it within reach of the consumers. There will be options that importers can do. If a payment agreement is made. the initial down payment will be collected by the City Watch. and the item will be released. The City Watch will pay the importer the remaining amount in full. And Within reason. the remaining amount must be paid to the city watch by the purchaser. If the purchaser fails to do so. The city watch will place a hold on said person's bank account and take what is owed. Or continue to collect from the bank account until the amount is paid in full.\\n\\nIn my opinion. I feel a start-up guild that was hired for a job that requires materials that is not regularly offered within the city. would now have a chance to negotiate a price to obtain an item. And complete the job so they can grow as a business and a guild. The City Watch can be the mediators and make sure all transactions are completed as agreed. Thus any hoarding of materials for the sole purpose of price inflation can come to an end. The current bidding wars that take place at the auctions will also come to an end and prices of goods will be reduced as a result. Thus opening up more opportunities for the common joe to succeed and not turn to a life of crime by stealing what they need.\\n \\n In the interest in keeping houses from placing unreasonably high prices on items. In my opinion, I believe that a 30% mark up on the actual cost of import. Would be the standard benchmark for a starting price. And or the bare minimum accepted for the item. That way the house can still turn a profit. And the prices of items stay reasonable and affordable for the everyday start-up guild. After all, the entire idea of this is to end wars such as the steel wars most of us have lived through and have to pay five hundred. Even up to one thousand denarii for a single rod of plain..boring steel. Something of this nature would allow all to benefit from the import. All will make a profit. And all prices would be sane. The cost is a mere estimate. It will all depend on the location of the warehouse and what the city decides.\\n", "comments":([ \:([ "comment":"As I hear, security is a concern for this. These items would come to the warehouse, where the customer could make the purchase there without muss or fuss. Each Embassy could assign guards, or the city could assign constabulary guards, or this city watch, though it would take some rather vigorous oversight on such an organization.\\r\\nI also think that perhaps the funds for such a building could be raised between the four embassies, the Sailors. ([ "body":"I often notice people complaining about Houses taking on crafters but they never stop to find out why. It is entirely difficult to be a new crafter and perhaps some of you forget this so I'll refresh your memory. \\n\\nWhen I first started crafting, I was bullied, taunted and threatened by mister Clover and his members all because I did not wish to join his Jewelry guild. Before he left town he and his members did many things to try and stop my attempt to become a Jeweler unless I joined them. Refused to sell lessons, they made extremely high bets on materials and just made everything difficult. I couldn't stand on my own, I mean the church aided me but all of the coin got used on the high cost of guild teachers and the high cost of materials. \\n\\nI eventually left my guild and tried to join more established guilds. I tried three different guilds and in each one the owners left. Leaving me with not much to do since I had no say in their guild. This caused me to have to find another. Eventually a house offered aid. For my services they would provide my final lessons. I took this deal since there weren't many options and now I'm doing better than I ever have. I still pay for my own materials and I teach others either free or at a low price because unlike those before me, I'd love to see more crafters in town.\\n\\nSo the point of this lengthy complaint is that crafters need to work together and help when you can. Stop the bullying, stop being underhanded for light sakes, would people stop buying materials and then reselling them at a higher price. The Houses aren't the problems, they have only helped where others have failed to.\\n", "comments":([ \:([ "comment":"Who is doing the bullying exactly? You named one person who has not been present in the city in a very long time.\\r\\n\\r\\nWhen I first arrived in town, I joined a guild and very shortly after, a House made a deal with the leader and began to tell us what we were allowed to make and who we were allowed to sell to. This did not sit well with me because in this city, crafters have the RIGHT to work independently. I left all resources behind to form my own guild. I had nothing and everything I earned was by hard work and forming friendships with other independent guilds AND by working with the embassies to form mutually beneficial contracts. We did not bully or threaten, we supported each other and through this support, we were able to thrive. I do not have rebellious feelings against embassies at all but it is a FACT that labor should be performed by commoner guilds. What do you think happens when jobs are taken from the working people? They get desperate. When people get desperate, either crime goes up or they just leave the city.\\r\\n\\r\\nYou said joining the embassy was the answer yet you still pay for your own materials. How was having your own guild not an option when you pay for your own materials anyway? Just to give history on MY experiences...\\r\\n\\r\\nI have invested thousands upon thousands of denarii in lessons and materials for other smiths. I have devoted more time and energy in them than I can say. Do you know how many have left my guild at the drop of a hat because a house made them an offer they can't refuse? Six that I can name right off the top of my head. If they want to leave to form their own guilds, that is one thing. But for an embassy to benefit from the hard work and resources I dumped into an individual's training? That is wrong.\\r\\n\\r\\nThe point is that commoner guilds should not have to competed with embassies when it comes to the crafts. I can and have and will continue to work with embassies when I am able and when they allow it. But a house poaching crafters and taking work from the guilds is wrong.", "time":1480106087 ]), \:([ "comment":"It's one thing for a House to take a crafter from an active guild and it's another for a House to aid a crafter who has no where else to go.\\r\\nI am uncertain on smith crafters but there has never been many Jewelers, the ones I spoke about were all in mister Clover's guild. While they are gone now they weren't when I was anew crafter and needed help because they refused to do anything kind because I didn't wish to join their guild.\\r\\nI joined the embassy because they aided me with my lessons so I could use my coin to build up my materials which was and still is difficult since people often send extreme bids. For example, the rods that are upon the boards now are not my bid. If there is only two jewelers in town why are the bidding prices going so high?\\r\\nIt's because other guilds and merchants are bidding on them, so please do not try and claim the houses are at fault. The other guilds have their faults also.\\r\\n--\\r\\nAlso, I completely understand that the items are rare and when crafters are in need it gets high. What I don't get however is that if the city only has two jewelers and neither jeweler is bidding on the material because someone made it so high then we know two things. Someone who doesn't need it is bidding and the crafters who do need it are losing out, meaning the city is also losing out.\\r\\nSo my complaint isn't that the houses are charging too much but that other guilds are buying up things they don't -need- and some crafters tend to be unkind and unhelpful to new crafters. Leaving them with no other help. We should be working together to build more cafters instead of trying keep all the work for just one person or group.\\r\\n\\r\\n--\\r\\n\\r\\nYes I can ask my house for supplies but so can anyone else, my house would not deny anyone the right to bet on materials that they need or want. It's not hard at all to write a scroll. And no, I don't have unlimited funds to throw at materials. I wish I did but no I don't.", "time":1480430227 ]), \:([ "comment":"Half of all active crafters in this city are held by Houses. And if the rods are high, it proves only that demand is high. ([ "body":"I would like to propose a Triskellian City Watch group to be stationed in Docktown. This group would be comprised of volunteers who care for the safety and security of the guilds--not just in Docktown but in all of Triskellian. The City Watch would not be a law-enforcement group and so would work with the Constabulary to ensure law processes are being followed.\\n\\nPURPOSE\\nThe City Watch will look out for the safety of the people and enforce guild rights. Responsbilities include, but are not limited to:\\n* Patrolling Docktown to ensure the main streets are safe for travel.\\n* Providing escort to those who do not feel safe traveling alone.\\n* Act as mediators during House vs. Guild disputes.\\n* Enforce the trade laws that are passed to protect the rights of the guilds (reporting violations to the council, collecting fines from violators).\\n\\nThe City Watch will NOT be responsible for:\\n* Filing crime reports (only constables have this authority).\\n* Arresting wanted criminals.\\n\\nSTRUCTURE\\nThe group would be led by a council appointed Commander. The Commander would be responsible for recruiting and ensuring that the group fulfills its purpose. The Commander is free to organize the group as he or she deems fit but may be removed from the position by the Council if it is determined that:\\n* The Commander is abusing his or her position of power.\\n* The Commander takes an unannounced leave of absence.\\n* The Commander fails to fulfill the group's aforementioned purpose.\\n\\nJOINING THE WATCH\\nOnly non-House members are permitted to join. The Commander will handle the application process as he or she deems appropriate.\\n\\nHEADQUARTERS\\nI propose that the old jailhouse be used as a headquarters for this operation with no structural modifications to the building itself.\\n\\n* Main room: On-duty watchmen are stationed here. Bell that can be rang from the Newtown gate (rope/bell system).\\n* Hallway: Guard that allows/denies access to rooms.\\n* Room west of hallway: Barracks for off-duty watchmen.\\n* Cells (right of hallway): Can be used for storage, armory, medical station, etc.\\n\\nRESOURCES\\n* Guard for the hallway (~1000 denarii)\\n* Supplies, furniture, storage, whatever we need to furnish the building (~250 denarii)\\n* Rope/bell system (4 ropes, pulleys use existing bell in the main room ~200 denarii)\\n* Armbands to signify loyalty to the watch (~100 denarii)\\n* TOTAL: 1550 denarii. Bruno Smith is willing to donate the funds to support this endeavor.\\n\\nOOC Notes:\\n* This is still a public space so we should try to keep access fairly open. No one room should only be accessible by 1 or 2 people alone. If we need to restrict anything, we can use locked storage containers.\\n* All council members should be on the guard's allow list to show that the building is council controlled and not controlled by any single person or guild. We should also be unrestrictive about who can join the city watch.\\n\\nINCENTIVES AND COMPENSATION\\nThe City Watch will offer the following incentives and compensation to members:\\n* Free armor and weapon maintenance (to be handled by select guilds)\\n* Free medical treatment (to be handled by select guilds)\\n* 5% bonus to individuals who successfully collect a fine\\n* 100% of any monetary tips that are collected when providing escort or mediation services\\n", "comments":([ ]), "filedby":"Bruno", "guild":"The Hands of St. Trahern", "title":"Establishing City Watch group" ])

Any non-guild crafter discovered to be advertising their wares, such as utilizing the trade tables or public posts, would be in violation of this agreement and their respective employer would be fined 1000 denarii.", "comments":([ \:([ "comment":"In response to the inquiries about this suggestion, I have written up a response to the questions that were asked:\\r\\n\\r\\n1) Who is required to obtain a license?\\r\\n\\r\\nAny crafter who is employed by a Great House, Church, or Constabulary.
